data.body:

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1 x64
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

Launch vscode from git bash.
`$ code .`

Open the terminal run some commands to fill the windows.

Then try to clear the windows. `CTRL + L` or `clear`.

ps: If I launch vscode from the system  everything works fine.

I have git bash in the terminal window inside vscode

data.title: File suggestions for Node require() function
data.body: It is quite annoying to keep working out the exact file path of a .js or .json file every time I want to include something, especially if I have to traverse backwards. Would it be possible to use the directory of the current document and the relative file being typed in to list file results that I would want to include?

data.title: TextDocument.isClosed = true even when document is not closed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open some 2 documents within the same editor
2. Switch from one to another document

Explanation:

Both _**onDidChangeActiveTextEditor**_ and _**onDidCloseTextDocument**_ events are fired. On the latter one, document's property _**isClosed**_ is set to _**true**_, even if it is not closed (it just lost focus).

I need the information if some file is actually closed, not just if focus switched from it to some another file.

data.title: Emmet Abbreviatio not working with number endings
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

Since the last two or three updates, my VS Code is not automatically showing suggestions for snippets ending with numbers. I use VS Code for web development (HTML, CSS, JS, and PHP), and the issue only occurs on PHP files. In HTML files all are ok.

Example: to create a Bootstrap col-xs-12, we just need to type ".col-xs-12" and press Tab in HTML, but in PHP is not working (but, with snippets that not ends with numbers - tested with fictional ".col-xs" and ".col-xs-12e" - works fine).

PS: no extensions are installed

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64 15063.540

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Insert some code snippet ending with numbers (like .col-xs-12 for creating a bootstrap formatted div)
2. Autocompletion not shows automatically (needs to press Ctrl + Space to show dropdown)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Implement Intellisense Suggestion Mode
data.body:
When intellisense suggestions is open it auto selects the first option. Please provide an option to disable that. I think this is called suggestion mode in Visual Studio - https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/zainnab/2010/01/22/intellisense-suggestion-mode/ 

Why?
-----
Apart from the use case outlined in the linked article, when there is no default suggestion the TAB key can be reconfigured to cycle through suggestions and then use enter to accept a suggestion. When no suggestion is selected, enter key will insert a new line. Currently this behaviour is impossible as far as I know.

data.title: List all open files in the ... more tab menu
data.body:
To the right of the opened tabs in VS Code is the "more" ellipsis, ( ... ). Clicking this provides an option to "Show Opened Editors", which lists all open files in a Ctrl-P style drop menu. This works, but it requires an extra mouse click (on "Show Opened Editors") before you can select the file you wish to switch to.

Keyboard users will of course know the correct short cut to directly show the Ctrl-P style drop list, but is there a reason as to why mouse users are required to perform an extra step? Could VS Code instead just list the opened editors directly in the "more" menu like other editors?

Compare the attached screenshots showing VS Code vs Visual Studio. In Visual Studio, the opened files are directly listed and can immediately be selected.

I would like an option for VS Code to behave like Visual Studio does.

My apologies is this has been asked or discussed before. I tried searching, but without knowing the extra terminology that VS Code uses, any search becomes a generic "list all files" sort of query, which doesn't help.


- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. See above, and screenshots for reference

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

VS Code:
![vscode](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/414204/29995001-8dd45d26-9032-11e7-828c-c329af32f18c.png)

Visual Studio:
![vs](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/414204/29995002-951abf62-9032-11e7-8132-d9615eb5959f.png)

data.body:

- OS Version: Windows 10.0.15063

Steps to Reproduce:

1. The `settings.json` of my vscode 

```
    "files.encoding": "utf8",
    "files.autoGuessEncoding": true,
```

2. Ceate two txt files, make sure the files are saved as `utf-8`

test1.txt
```
Created on: 2017年9月2日
测
```

test2.txt
```
Created on: 2017年9月2日
测试
```

3. Reopen the files,`test1.txt` guessed encoding is `Windows 1252` and `test2.txt` guessed encoding is `utf-8`.

data.title: Implement "Go Last"
data.body: This implements a "Go Last" command. This command will navigate either forward or backwards in history to the last entry in the history stack you were looking at. I've implemented this in service of implementing `''` and `` for vim mode: https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim/issues/1089

data.title: Detect Markdown references links
data.body:
**Feature Request**
For the markdown:

```markdown
text [more info][autosave] text

[autosave]: /docs/editor/codebasics.md#saveauto-save
```

Detect `autosave` in `[autosave]` as a link to `/docs/editor/codebasics.md#saveauto-save`

Related to #25861

data.title: URL escaping is changed when using "Loaded Scripts" viewlet
data.body:
chrome-debug sends ` {"seq":0,"type":"event","event":"script","body":{"reason":"new","script":{"id":11,"source":{"name":"test2.js","path":"http://localhost:8080/out/client%20with%20space/test2.js","sourceReference":1001}}}}` (with `%20` escaped spaces)

I open test2.js from "loaded scripts" and set a breakpoint in it. VS Code sends `setBreakpoints({"source":{"path":"http://localhost:8080/out/client with space/test2.js","name":"test2.js"},"lines":[3],"breakpoints":[{"line":3}],"sourceModified":false})` (with unescaped spaces)

data.title: vscode cannot show GUI on Ubuntu (Ubuntu bash on Win10 with Xserver installed on Win10 host)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1-1502903936
- OS Version:
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS
Release:        16.04
Codename:       xenial
**-Additional**:
Actually the environment is the "Ubuntu bash on Win10" with Xserver installed on Win10 to show the GUI.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install the VS code through command line in "Ubuntu bash on Win10"
2. Install the Xserver on Win10.
3. Start the Xserver on Win10, and then type command: "code" in Ubuntu bash.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Results:
VS code CANNOT show GUI. However, the Xserver show that there are clients connected to it. (Also running other program on Ubuntu bash, such as "gedit", which can show GUI in Xserver correctly.)

data.title: workspace.asRelativePath on windows returns modified string for failure
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:05:38.342Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
better-toml|bun|0.2.0
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.2.0
autoimport|ste|1.2.2



---
initially found with VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.16.0-insider (aa42e6ef8184e8ab20ddaa5682b861bfb6f0b2ad, 2017-09-01T15:40:17.463Z)

workspace.asRelativePath returns unexpected values in two ways:

`workspace.asRelativePath(workspace.rootPath)` does not return '' or './'

ok, so the documentation says 
> ...or when the path * is not a child of that folder, the input is returned.

I'll give that part of it a pass, as the root is technically not a child.

It does, however, return a modified string, instead of the input: the input's drive backslash is returned as a forward slash.
```
const wksRoot = workspace.rootPath;  // e:\foo
const rel = workspace.asRelativePath(wksRoot) // e:/foo
```

This is not specific to the root, however.  Any \ gets converted to /

`const rel = workspace.asRelativePath('D:\\BAR\\FOO') // d:/bar/foo`


expected behavior is to actually return the input as specified, so the following code would be valid:
```
const rel = workspace.asRelativePath(testPath);
if (testPath === rel) { // do non-relative path things }

```
having to do a separate test for (testPath === workspace.rootPath) is not ideal, either.   How is this intended to be handled for the multi-root feature?  Will it still return the testPath?
Perhaps now would be a great time to make this feature more usable, and create a better function that clarifies and makes more usable the different use cases, rather than the current solution of having asRelativePath report different things depending on the project setup (yuk!) and environment

suggested api:
```
export interface IRelativePathResult {
  relativePath: string,
  foundRoot: string
}
export function getRelativePath(pathOrUri: string | Uri): IRelativePathResult;

```
result is null for path not related
result.relativePath is '' if the input was a root path, or the full relative path
result.foundRoot is the closest root (or the input if exact match)

ideally:
```
if(typeof inputPath === 'string') {
  assert (result.foundRoot + result.relativePath === inputPath);
}

```
but that could be a stretch goal

```
Uncaught Error: Cannot find module '/home/user/Documents/vscode-dev/vscode/out/vs/loader'

```

folders and file vscode/out/vs/loader doesn't exist.
try to find info for this error, but fale. Try to reinstall all, reclone all, used gulp clean - it did't help me.
What I'm doing wrong?

data.title: VS Code's Emmet will not wrap individual lines with <li> tag
data.body:
When using Emmet's "wrap with abbreviation" on a multi-line block of text, ul>li* (or ol>li*) creates a single list item rather than one list item per line. --- - VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T17:15:57.756Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0 - Extensions: Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- markdown-toc|Ala|1.5.6 replace-smart-characters|DrM|0.0.2 lorem-ipsum|Tyr|1.0.0 git-easy|bib|1.9.1 htmltagwrap|bra|0.0.3 jshint|dba|0.10.15 vscode-hasher|dee|1.0.1 ftp-simple|hum|0.5.5 HTMLHint|mka|0.3.3 stylelint|shi|0.28.0 vscode-preview-server|yui|0.7.0 --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. In .html file, select a series of lines separated by carriage returns ``` list 1 list 2 list 3 ``` 2. Press F1 to bring up command palette 3. Enter "Emmet: Wrap With Abbreviation" 4. Enter the abbreviation `ul>li* ` (as documented at https://docs.emmet.io/actions/wrap-with-abbreviation/#wrapping-individual-lines) Result: ```html
  • list 1 list 2 list 3
``` Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Allow language extensions to override editor.wordSeparators
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.15.1
- OS Version: Any

There's a pretty common request from PowerShell extension users to enable double-click selection of variable names like `$myVar` including the initial dollar sign character.  After some research it seems that the only way to control this double-click selection behavior is by having the user change their `editor.wordSeparators` setting to remove the `$` which is included by default.

Is there any way that a language extension can override this setting (or behavior) for a specific language aside from editing the user's settings file to add this setting?  If not, is it possible to programmatically add or edit a language-specific config section (like `[powershell]`) in the user's config?

Thanks!
